Award.AwardTitle: Geometry and Statistics on Spaces of Dynamical Systems for Pattern Recognition in High-Dimensional Time Series

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to develop a mathematical framework for efficiently comparing dynamical systems identified from high-dimensional time-series data as well as algorithms for clustering, classification, and statistical analysis of such data. Dynamical systems are widely used for the analysis, verification, and control of physical, mechanical, thermal, chemical and biological processes. However, there are many emerging applications in which one also needs to "compare the dynamics of two processes". In computer vision, for example, one can use dynamical models to describe kinematic and video data of human motion. While different people move differently, the dynamical models of two people performing the same task (e.g., walking) should be "closer" to each other than the models of two people performing different tasks (e.g., walking vs running). Framework will be developed for spaces of linear dynamical systems whose quotient structure is defined by the action of a group on a smooth manifold. A family of efficiently computable distances in the ambient space will be used to define a family of "group-action-induced distances" in the quotient space. Such distances will be used to develop methods for performing classification, clustering and statistical analysis on spaces of dynamical systems. These methods will be evaluated on kinematic and video data of human activities.

The development of methods for comparing dynamical models can impact both basic science and the society at large. In control theory, such methods can impact system identification and robust control. In computer vision, such techniques can be used to discriminate human and crowd activities in video data, which is relevant to many applications in surveillance, security, traffic monitoring, sports coverage/broadcast, human-computer interaction, etc. This project will train engineers and scientist in multidisciplinary research that will need concepts from differential geometry, machine learning, and computer vision. As such, it can potentially impact many other related fields. This project will also impact many diversity outreach activities, including ongoing REU programs, the Women in Science and Engineering (WISE) program and summer camps for K-12 outreach. Datasets and code will be made publicly accessible for research and educational purposes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has furthered our knowledge about spaces of linear dynamical systems (LDSs) and helped train one post-doc researcher.

The significance of LDSs is that they are powerful tools to model a wide range of dynamic phenomena in various disciplines of science and engineering, e.g., computer vision, control engineering, econometrics. In all these disciplines, it often happens that one needs to compare LDSs for various tasks such as classification, clustering, etc. As such, the notion of a distance between LDSs becomes relevant. In this project, we derived the mathematical foundations for the “alignment distance” as a distance on the manifolds of LDSs of fixed input-output size and fixed state-space order. Such manifolds are complicated (highly nonlinear) spaces and their study in the past had not resulted in useful computational tools. One source of this difficulty is that they are quotient spaces under a group action and hence possess complicated topologies. In the case of LDS manifolds, the action is the change of basis in the state-space or the so-called similarity action by GL(n), GL(n) being the group of n by n nonsingular matrices and n being the order of the state of systems which is assumed to be fixed. Our basic idea in defining the alignment distance is to consider a system as an equivalence class of its state-space realizations all related by the similarity action, and hence finding the best state-space change of basis that brings a realization of one system closest to a realization of another system.  We used tools from advanced differential geometry such as the notion of “reduction of the structure group” to perform reduction-steps, where the action of GL(n) is reduced to O(n), its subgroup of orthogonal matrices, without sacrificing topological information which is vital in defining a distance loyal to the original quotient topology. As a result of a reduction-step, the computation of the alignment distance becomes a tractable finite dimensional optimization problem. We have identified various such reduction-steps already in the literature (used for other applications) and introduced many others; in all cases we provided rigorous proofs of their validity. One major technical finding has been that various notions of realization or Gramian balancing (long in use in the control theory literature) are examples of such a differential-geometric reduction-step.

We showed that the alignment distance is a versatile and general distance in the sense that it can be defined for both deterministic and stochastic systems, stable and unstable systems, and in particular systems with many inputs and outputs. We showed that in its general form the alignment distance can also include various forms of internal and external symmetries induced by groups, e.g., the case of stochastic systems with Gaussian inputs can be considered as an example with a symmetry group acting on the input. Preliminary studies showed that the alignment distance could be extended to certain important classes of nonlinear and time-varying systems such as Linear Parameter Varying Systems (LPVs).

We used the alignment distance to define statistical notions such as average (mean) or median for LDSs. Means or medians on spaces of LDSs can be used for various applications such as classification of videos or for improving system identification algorithms through an aggregation process.  We further developed methodologies to generate random systems, e.g., random systems uniformly distributed in a region around a given system, for applications such simulation of robustness of systems under random perturbations.

Using the basic ideas behind the definition of the alignment distance, we showed that one can revisit certain problems in control theory. In particular, we showed how to metrize the Kalman decomposition and use such a metrization for solving the old and important problem of “model order reduction” (MOR) in control theory. By “metrization” we mean comparison of Kalman decompositions using a metric. In MOR, one finds a LDS “closest” of order r

The results of this project were (and further will be) published as articles in major conference proceedings and journals. Software code implementing the derived algorithms is available to public for free from our Lab’s website.
